nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Week 2 after separation. You both agree a parenting plan is needed soon.

choices.label: Mediation-first: neutral mediator drafts a plan
DIY plan: draft together, validate with a social worker
Lawyered: each retains counsel to shape a formal agreement

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You book a mediator and set ground rules for respectful meetings.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You create a shared doc and list the big topics to cover.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Consultations begin. Communication becomes more formal.

nodes.summary: End of Act 1. You set a starting lane.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You begin drafting schedules, holidays, communication rules, and decision-making.

nodes.prompt: How detailed should the plan be at first?

choices.label: Start simple: core schedule and 2 clear rules
Moderate detail: schedule, holidays, and a check-in process
Full detail now: every scenario covered

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You capture the essentials to test in the real world.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You balance clarity with flexibility and add a review cadence.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You push for completeness, which takes longer but feels thorough.

nodes.summary: End of Act 2. A first draft is on paper.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Two topics are hard: handover times and travel permissions.

nodes.prompt: How do you work through disagreement?

choices.label: Take a 10-minute break, return with one compromise each
Escalate: bring in mediator or neutral third party
Dig in and argue point by point

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You trade concessions and write a workable compromise.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: A neutral helps reframe interests and offers a middle path.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: The tone worsens and progress stalls.

nodes.summary: End of Act 3. You either made progress or built tension.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You review the draft against the child's needs and your capacity.

choices.label: Sign a 60-day pilot and schedule a review
Partial agreement now, keep negotiating a few items
No deal for now; move to formal legal process

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You commit to a pilot and a clear review date to adjust.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You bank progress and keep talks focused on remaining items.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You hand it to counsel. Timelines and tone likely change.

nodes.summary: End of Act 4. You leave with a plan, partial plan, or escalation.
